awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF:RI:Small:Collaborative Research:Next-Generation Multi-Agent Path Finding Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
With the increased use of automated vehicles in manufacturing, warehousing, and other environments, it is important to ensure that the plans taken by the automated agents controlling these vehicles are both efficient and safe. That is, we want to minimize the cost of travel while ensuring that agents will not collide with each other or the environment. This project will focus particularly on approaches for planning in environments where the number of agents is limited, but the cost of failure is high. For instance, in an airport there are relatively few airplanes moving on the tarmac at any one time, but the cost of collisions is large. The project will develop efficient and robust approaches that can be used to control agents in these environments. When these approaches are complete, this will enable new applications for the deployment of automated agents that can reduce the cost and pollution of current systems while increasing their efficiency and safety.

Existing algorithms for centralized control of agents have three drawbacks. First, they often make restrictive assumptions about the environment, such as axis-aligned movement with unit-cost actions. Second, the optimal approaches do not scale to large numbers of agents and the fastest algorithms have poor solution quality. Third, these algorithms are only well-defined in fixed scenarios where there is a clear distinction between plan formation and execution. This project will address these limitations by developing new algorithms. These approaches will handle more realistic agent models, such as robotic movement on a state lattice, they will compute near-optimal solutions to ensure that they scale to significantly larger scenarios, and they will be adapted to run on online problems where agents can enter or exit the world and where plan execution is imprecise and must be adapted based on real-world restrictions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: NSF and US-Israel Binational Science Fou

por.por_cntn:
200 - 800 words

 

There are many growing applications of autonomous of AI agents in the world, from robots in Amazon warehouses to self-driving cars. The task of getting a variety of agents to their goals without colliding is called Multi-Agent Pathfinding (MAPF). Each application of MAPF has different requirements for safety, robustness, centralized vs decentralized control, and many other parameters. These depend on the capabilities of the AI agents, whether or not they are working with humans, the cost of the agents, and the risks of failure.

 

The work in this project was focused on MAPF algorithms for centralized agent control. Centralized control cannot scale to the same sizes of decentralized control, and would typically be used for scenarios where the agents are expensive, or the cost of mistakes (either to human life or other property) is large enough that they are not tolerated. Airport surface operations and an example domain that fit this requirement as the cost of collisions between aircraft is significant.

 

A majority of the work in MAPF for centralized agent control is based on the Conflict-Based Search (CBS) algorithm. This algorithms decomposes the problem to solve individual agents independently, communicating constraints between agents to resolve potential conflicts. At the beginning of this project, the majority of work on CBS-like algorithms focused on very simple grid domains, where all actions by all agents are synchronized and have the same cost.

 

In this project we significantly extended the application of CBS to real-world domains by extended it to allow for asynchronous actions and non-uniform costs. While some work had developed specialized approaches for individual cases, we developed a general mechanism for finding conflicts between agents and integrating these conflicts into search. This general approach is able to find and resolve large sets of conflicts simultaneously, significantly reducing the cost of finding solutions. Other work around this has developed new algorithms and combined existing algorithms in novel ways to improve overall performance in MAPF problems, with a particular focus on more problems with more complex costs.

 

Given a surge of recent interest in MAPF algorithms, we also wrote a survey paper that provided a broad overview of problem domains, cost models, and other problem variants. This paper also proposed MAPF benchmark problems that could be used for more standard evaluation of agents across research projects. This survey paper has received over 500 citations in the past 5 years, and has widely been used as the canonical definition for MAPF problems.

 


Last Modified: 05/09/2024
Modified by: Nathan Sturtevant
